thread.title: Healing touch clinic on Townsville university grounds closes after social media backlash - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Healing touch clinic on Townsville university grounds closes after social media backlash - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Abc North Qld
title: Healing touch clinic on Townsville university grounds closes after social media backlash - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
A healing touch energy therapy clinic operating on the James Cook University Townsville campus in north Queensland has closed just days after opening amidst a social media backlash. 
Healing touch is described as an energy therapy similar to reiki or acupressure. 
The clinic officially opened on February 10, but on February 20 the university issued a statement saying they had closed the enterprise. 
The statement said the university was not involved in the running of the clinic. 
"James Cook University (JCU) has decided that the clinic will no longer operate on its campus," the statement said. 
"JCU had no contractual or financial relationship with the clinic and was not involved in the running of the clinic. 
"JCU staff were not employed to work at the clinic. 
"JCU does not promote nor teach Healing Touch in its science-based nursing programs." 
A Facebook video of the clinic's practitioners working on patients attracted varied commentary in the days after the clinic's opening. External Link: FB HT video 
"What the quackery? Is having your chi balanced covered by Medicare?" wrote Colin Dooley. 
"I don't understand why JCU would allow a space on campus to be rented by the clinic as it infers and (sic) endorsement by JCU," wrote Snombat Linda. 
"People may laugh and make fun of what they don't understand, but I congratulate you, JCU," wrote Louise Judges. 
The operators of the clinic, Healing Touch Townsville, are meeting this week to discuss the decision. 
The ABC has approached both JCU and the clinic's operators for comment.
